etymology.description: 言(言) (yán, "word, speak") + 斥(斥) (chì, "accuse, blame") = to accuse verbally -> complain/tell
etymology.interpretation: The character combines 言(言) (yán, "word, speak") to denote verbal action with 斥(斥) (chì, "accuse, blame") to imply making a complaint or expressing discontent. This reflects the character's meaning of expressing or communicating grievances.
etymology.simplification: Simplified by replacing 訁 (one of the forms of 言) with 讠, which is a more cursive and simplified form.

examples.chinese: 她向朋友诉说烦恼(她向朋友訴說煩惱)。
examples.english: She confided her troubles to her friend.

examples.chinese: 他向官员诉苦(他向官員訴苦)，希望得到公正(希望得到公正)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiàng guānyuán sùkǔ, xīwàng dédào gōngzhèng.
examples.english: He complained to the officials, hoping to obtain justice.

examples.chinese: 村民纷纷向官府诉冤(村民紛紛向官府訴冤)。
examples.english: Villagers urgently appealed to the government to redress their grievances.
